questions.text: The audiogram of a patient with difficulty in hearing is given below. What is your interpretation?
questions.solution:
The patient has left-sided conductive hearing loss. 

Interpretation of the above audiogram:

  • Blue color indicates left ear.
  • ] indicates BC and threshold is <25dB. BC is normal which means the sensorineural pathway is normal.
  • × indicates AC and threshold is >15 dB and hence AC is abnormal.
  • So, it indicates conductive deafness.
  • The air-bone gap is a feature of conductive hearing loss.
  • Hence, the chart is suggestive of left-sided conductive deafness.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to the ENT OPD with complaints of difficulty in hearing. A pure tone audiometry test is performed and the result is given below. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
The given pure tone audiometry is suggestive of right-sided sensorineural deafness.

Interpretation of the result:

  • Red indicates the right ear.
  • O indicates air conduction(AC). The threshold here is >15 dB indicating abnormal AC.
  • < indicates bone conduction(BC). The threshold is >25 dB indicating abnormal BC.
  • Both AC and BC are abnormal which indicates a sensorineural hearing loss.
  • There is no air-bone gap.
  • Hence, it is right side sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: The audiogram of a patient who presented with a gradually progressive hearing loss is given below. Which among the following would be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given audiogram is seen in Ménière's disease in its early stages. It shows an upsloping/ascending curve suggesting that the lower frequencies are affected first.

Presbycusis, ototoxicity, and sound-induced hearing loss have downsloping audiograms since the higher frequencies are affected first in these conditions.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with hearing loss that developed shortly after her first pregnancy. Her audiometry report is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a patient with post-pregnancy hearing loss. The audiogram shows conductive deafness along with Carhart's notch (dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz). These findings are highly suggestive of otosclerosis. 

Ototoxicity, Meniere’s disease, and noise-induced hearing loss cause sensory neural hearing loss (SNHL) and not conductive hearing loss.

Otosclerosis is caused by bony overgrowth involving the enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule. It presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and can worsen with stress and hormonal changes like during pregnancy and menopause. 

Stapedial otosclerosis is the most common type of otosclerosis. Here the lesion starts just in front of the oval window in an area called fistula ante fenestrae.

The presence of a reddish hue on the promontory through the tympanic membrane, known as the Schwartze sign, suggests an active focus. PTA shows loss of air conduction with air-bone gap, more for lower frequencies and Carhart's notch may be seen. Tympanometry shows an As type of tympanogram in which there is reduced compliance at or near the ambient air pressure.

Medical management with sodium fluoride is used in the active stage. Definitive treatment is stapedectomy/stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis. Carhart notch usually disappears after a successful stapedectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Ototoxicity causes SNHL and shows a high-frequency hearing loss in the SNHL curve.

Option B: In Meniere's disease, pure tone audiometry shows an SNHL pattern with a rising curve in the early stages (as lower frequencies are involved first) and as the disease progresses higher frequencies are involved, the curve becomes flat or a falling type.

Option D: Noise-induced hearing loss is SNHL and PTA shows a characteristic acoustic dip at 4000 Hz both for air and bone conduction.

questions.text: A prisoner who was brought to the hospital with deafness after a brawl with another inmate is suspected of malingering. Which of the following tests can be used to assess the authenticity of his complaints?
questions.solution:
Impedance audiometry can be used to test malingering. It is an objective test and consists of tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurements.

A person who feigns total deafness and does not give any response on pure tone audiometry but shows a positive acoustic reflex is a malingerer.

questions.text: A patient with hearing loss is being evaluated with the following instrument. What is the frequency of the probe used?
questions.solution:
The given image shows impedance audiometry and the frequency of the probe used here is 220 Hz.

Impedance audiometry consists of tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurements.

Tympanometry equipment consists of a probe that snugly fits into the external auditory canal and has three channels.

  • To deliver a tone of 220Hz
  • To absorb reflected sound
  • To change the pressure in EAC

questions.text: The tympanogram of a young patient who presented with a progressive hearing loss is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The tympanogram shows As type of curve suggestive of otosclerosis. It indicates that pressure is normal but compliance is reduced.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: Using impedance audiometry, stapedial reflexes are being assessed in a child with cranial nerve palsy. Which of the following cranial nerves is being tested here?
questions.solution:
The 7th and 8th cranial nerves are being tested in a child by assessing the stapedial reflexes. 

The afferent of stapedial reflex is the 8th cranial nerve and efferent is the 7th cranial nerve.

Related Pearl: Stapedial reflex

Principle: A loud sound of 70- 100dB above the hearing threshold of the patient, leads to bilateral contraction of the stapedius muscle.

Afferent: 8th cranial nerve.

Efferent: 7th cranial nerve.

Centre: Superior olivary complex in the brainstem.

In afferent palsy, the reflex is absent on both sides, and in efferent palsy reflex is absent only on the side of the lesion.

Clinical significance:

  • Can identify malingerers.
  • To differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- the threshold is decreased in cochlear lesions because of recruitment whereas it is increased or even absent in retrocochlear lesions.
  • Identify the site of the facial nerve lesion- its presence indicates that the lesion is beyond the nerve to stapedius.

Acoustic reflex decay- it is a feature of retrocochlear hearing loss (8th nerve lesion). A sustained tone of 500-1000Hz delivered 10dB above the acoustic reflex threshold, for a period of 10 seconds, brings the amplitude to 50% (abnormal decay).

questions.text: What is the instrument shown below?
questions.solution: The instrument shown is Barany’s noise box which is used to mask non-test ear while testing bone conduction.

questions.text: A woman is brought by her son to the ENT OPD due to hearing problems. He says that she always requests him to speak loud and whenever he speaks slightly louder, she tells him to stop shouting. Which of the following is the likely cause for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given symptom is indicative of a recruitment phenomenon and is seen in cochlear hearing loss (e.g. Ménière’s disease and presbycusis). It refers to abnormal growth of loudness. 

It is tested by ABLB (Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance) test. Lesser intensity sounds are heard louder in the normal ear. However, a greater intensity sound is heard equally, or even better in the abnormal ear. This is referred to as abnormal growth of loudness.

However, in the conductive hearing loss, a constant difference of intensity is maintained throughout.

questions.text: Patient with hearing loss undergoes speech audiometry whose report is given below. What is it suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The given speech audiometry shows roll-over phenomenon suggestive of retrocochlear hearing loss. 

With an increase in speech intensity above a particular level, the speech discrimination score falls rather than maintaining a plateau as seen in the cochlear type of sensorineural hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Speech audiometry

Consists of two components:

  • Speech reception threshold: The minimum intensity at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient.
  • Speech discrimination score: The patient’s ability to understand speech.
    • Percentage of phonetically balanced words delivered 30dB above SRT which are identified correctly.
    • In normal persons and those with conductive hearing loss, a high score of 90–100% can be obtained.
    • It is reduced in cochlear lesions, very poor and out of proportion to hearing loss in retrocochlear hearing loss, and worst in cortical deafness.

Roll-over phenomenon:

  • Feature of retrocochlear hearing loss.
  • When speech intensity is increased above a particular level, SDS falls instead of maintaining a plateau as in cochlear deafness.

Uses:

  • To differentiate organic from non-organic hearing loss.
  • To differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.
  • To find the intensity at which discrimination score is the best which is useful for fitting a hearing aid.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to you with a progressive hearing loss accompanied by tinnitus. An MRI of the patient with gadolinium contrast is given below. Which of the following results is consistent with the diagnosis?

choices.text: <25 dB decay in threshold tone decay test

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the MRI are suggestive of vestibular schwannoma which is a retrocochlear disease. The presence of otoacoustic emissions is a feature consistent with the diagnosis.

Vestibular schwannoma typically presents at 40-60 years of age. Progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, often accompanied by tinnitus, is the presenting symptom in the majority of cases.

The MRI shows left cerebellopontine angle mass causing widening of the porous acousticus. The mass is seen extending into intracanalicular portion of the internal acoustic meatus which is suggestive of vestibular schwannoma.

questions.text: What does summating potential in electrocochleography indicate?

choices.text: Electrical activity of distal part of auditory nerve

questions.solution:
Summating potential in electrocochleography indicates the sum of electrical activity in hair cells within the organ of Corti.

Electrocochleography (ECoG) is an objective test which records the electrical activity of the cochlea and 8th nerve in response to auditory stimuli. The recording electrode is passed through the tympanic membrane to rest over the promontory.

The three parameters measured in ECoG are:

  1. Cochlear microphonics – measures the electrical activity that follows the stimulus and reflects the instantaneous displacement of the basilar membrane.
  2. Summating potential (SP) – measures the electrical activity of the hair cells within the organ of Corti.
  3. Action potential (AP) – electrical activity in the distal part of the auditory nerve.

Normal SP: AP ratio is <30% but it is increased in Meniere’s disease.

questions.text: A preterm neonate with an Apgar score of 4 at 5 minutes of birth undergoes otoacoustic emission study.  Which of the following is false about this test?

choices.text: Otoacoustic emissions are generated by inner hair cells
It is used as a screening test for hearing loss in infants
Spontaneous type is present in 50% of normal individuals
Evoked type is present in all individuals with normal hearing

questions.solution:
The otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) are generated by the outer hair cells of the cochlea. Presence of otoacoustic emissions is used to test hearing in a high-risk neonate as given in the clinical scenario.

Related Pearl: OAEs - Otoacoustic emissions

It is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea.

It is of two types:

  • Spontaneous type- it is generated spontaneously and is present in 50% of normal individuals.
  • Evoked types- also called Kemp echoes or cochlear echoes, are generated in response to sound stimulus and found in all individuals with normal hearing. The two subtypes are transient evoked and distortion product.

The applications are as follows:

  • Screening test for neonates, infants, and small children for deafness due to inner ear causes.
  • Helps to differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- normal OAE indicates normal cochlea and hence retrocochlear pathology in a patient with sensorineural deafness.
  • Early detection of noise-induced hearing loss- since it is generated by outer hair cells that are prone to damage by noise trauma.

questions.text: Wave V in brainstem evoked response audiometry is produced by which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Wave V in BERA is produced by lateral lemniscus.

The generators of ABEPs (Auditory nerve and brainstem evoked potentials) have been the subject of much research and controversy and are still not entirely agreed upon.

The literature available to us states the following:

  • Scott Brown's Otorhinolaryngology- wave IV–V complex probably arises from neural activity within the superior olivary complex and nuclei of the lateral lemniscus, possibly some contribution from the inferior colliculus. So lateral lemniscus is the better option.
  • Current Diagnosis and Treatment in Otorhinolaryngology- auditory brainstem response waves 2, 3, 4, and 5 represent the sequential activation of neurons as the signal is passed up the brainstem from the proximal part of the cochlear nerve, cochlear nucleus, superior olivary complex, and lateral lemniscus. 
  • NIH Journals- generation of wave V reflects the activity of multiple anatomic auditory structures. A sharp positive peak of wave V arises mainly from the lateral lemniscus, following a slow negative wave represents dendritic potential in the inferior colliculus.

Considering the sources above we believe that it is better to mark lateral leminiscus if both options are present.

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: A patient undergoes hearing assessment using cortical evoked response audiometry. Which of the following is false regarding this test?

choices.text: Recording is made from cortical potentials

questions.solution:
In CERA or cortical evoked response audiometry, a tone stimulus is used instead of a click stimulus. 

It is an objective hearing test, that records the signals from the auditory cortex (part of the brain that recognizes sound) that have been generated in response to sounds introduced to the ears. 

The test gives information about the level of sound needed to produce a signal and confirms the status of the auditory cortex. This is valuable information that we can not obtain from a normal hearing test.

Difference between BERA and CERA:

BERA CERA
The recording is made from brain stem potentials The recording is made from cortical potentials
Click stimulus is used Tone stimulus is used
Responses are not frequency specific Responses are frequency specific
Can be performed in awake and restless patients The patient must lie still throughout the process
Responses begin after 1 -10 milliseconds after stimuli Responses begin after 50 – 300 milliseconds after stimulation
Suitable for even younger children Unsuitable for children

questions.text: As a medical officer in an occupational health program, you encounter an employee with hearing loss. You are suspicious that he is faking it to claim compensation. Which of the following tests is least useful in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of malingering and Rinne's test is least useful here.

Tests for malingering or nonorganic hearing loss:

  • Stenger test
  • Lombard test
  • Stapedial reflex
  • Inconsistent results on repeat pure tone and speech audiometry tests
  • BERA

questions.text: While performing a caloric test, what type of nystagmus would you expect on cold water irrigation?

choices.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side
Vertical nystagmus towards the same side
Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side

questions.solution:
In caloric testing, cold water irrigation produces horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side of irrigation. The direction of nystagmus can be remembered by the mnemonic, COWS (cold–opposite, warm–same). 

The mechanism for the nystagmus is the creation of a temperature gradient by the cold water, which pulls the cupula away from the utricle, causing nystagmus towards the oppsite side. As the horizontal semicircular canal is closer to the outer ear canal, most of the response comes from it and the nystagmus is horizontal.  

The Fitzgerald–Hallpike test (bithermal caloric test) is done to assess this phenomenon. The patient lies in a supine position with head tilted forward at a 30° angle, ensuring the horizontal canal becomes vertical. Alternatingly, water at temperatures of 30°C and 44°C (7° below and above normal body temperature, respectively) is irrigated into the ears for a duration of 40 seconds each. The examiner closely observes the patient's eyes for the emergence of nystagmus until its endpoint is reached. The time taken from the start of irrigation to the endpoint of nystagmus is recorded and plotted on a calorigram.

If no nystagmus is evoked from either ear, the test is repeated with water at a temperature of 20°C for a duration of 4 minutes before labeling the labyrinth dead. A 5-minute interval should be allowed between testing each ear to ensure accurate results.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing?
  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
BERA, OAE, and tympanometry are the objective tests for hearing. PTA (pure tone audiometry) is a subjective test for hearing as it relies on patient responses to pure tone stimuli. Other examples of subjective tests include tuning fork tests and speech audiometry.

Tympanometry is an objective test of the middle ear and eustachian tube functions (conductive compartment of hearing). Here, the compliance of the TM, i.e., how much it moves to the pressure differentials applied from the external ear is measured.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve
